metadata.case_name: Joint Hindu Family Firm (Appellants) v. Patiala State Bank

facts.text: The appellants are a joint Hindu family firm carrying on business since 1911 in grains, dal, cereals, cotton ginning and pressing, oil manufacture at Lehragaga in former State of Patiala.
The firm had a Cash Credit Account in Patiala State Bank, Lehragaga branch, borrowing on pledge of stocks.
In 1951-52, heavy slump in prices caused advances by Bank to exceed market prices of goods by Rs. 2,32,000/- for appellants' firm.
On May 23, 1953, Bank sanctioned Demand Loan of Rs. 4,50,000/-; firm deposited title deeds, executed promissory note and memorandum.

In 1951, firm Yogiraj Neelkumar started at Lehragaga with partners Bhagirathlal (senior member of appellants' family) and two strangers Kishore Chand, Banwarilal; had Cash Credit Account in Bank, owed Rs. 2,17,957-12-6 on May 23, 1953 due to slump.
Under arrangement May 23, 1953, Demand Loan adjusted towards shortfalls of both appellants' firm and Yogiraj Neelkumar.
Appellants contend they had nothing to do with Yogiraj Neelkumar; Bhagirathlal started it separately; family properties not liable for Rs. 2,17,957-12-6.
Bank took steps to recover under Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act and rules.
On Feb 17, 1955, Bank issued notice under Rule 3(2) for Rs. 5,17,863-3-4; appellants replied Mar 26, 1955 requesting instalments, postponement till compensation.
Nov 21, 1955, fresh notice for Rs. 5,24,593-10-10; appellants replied Dec 7, 1955 and Jan 6, 1956 requesting time.
Jan 27, 1956, Managing Director issued certificate under s.6 for Rs. 4,98,589-1-6 to Deputy Commissioner.
Appellants filed Writ Petition No. 133/1957 in Punjab HC on Feb 16, 1957 under Art.226 challenging Act and proceedings.
Jul 7, 1956, notice for Rs. 25,548-4-6 on cash credit; appellants denied; Oct 4, 1956 ex parte determination Rs. 25,478-15-9; Dec 6, 1956 notice under Rule 7(1); certificate issued.
May 17, 1958, Writ Petition No. 389/1958 challenging Oct 4, 1956 determination.
Punjab HC Mar 6, 1959 dismissed both writs, granted certificate under Art.133.
Appellants filed Art.32 petition challenging Act.
May 5, 1948 Covenant by Rulers of Faridkot, Jind etc. for Pepsu Union.
Pepsu came into existence Aug 20, 1948; Ordinance No.1 of 2005 BK by Raj Pramukh applying Patiala laws.
Feb 15, 1949 Ordinance No.16 of 2005 BK extending laws.
Apr 9, 1949 Supplementary Covenant amending Art.X omitting 6-month limit.
Writ Petition No.128/1959 by resident of former Nabha State challenging Act.
Petitioner in WP 128/1959 had mortgage to Bank Feb 20, 1951 for Rs.52,000; prior writ withdrawn after settlement Feb 3, 1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act had ceased to be in force on material dates due to expiry of Ordinances under Covenant.
Whether the Act and rules are repugnant to Articles 14 and 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution.
Whether certificate under s.6 issued in accordance with rules (countersignature).
Whether Supplementary Covenant valid and whether dispute barred by Art.363.

petitioner_arguments.text: Act ceased to be in force as Ordinances expired after 6 months under Art.X of Covenant; Supplementary Covenant void as Rulers lost sovereignty.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Covenant dated May 5, 1948; Art. VI, X

petitioner_arguments.text: Act and rules void under Art.13 as repugnant to Art.14 (discrimination vs other banks; post-reorg vs other Punjab areas) and Art.19(1)(f)(g) (unfair procedure, no natural justice, ouster of civil courts).
Certificates not countersigned by Minister/Secretary as required by proviso to s.6(1).
No liability for Yogiraj Neelkumar debt as separate concern.

respondent_arguments.text: Supplementary Covenant valid; Rulers retained competence; dispute barred by Art.363.
Patiala State Bank distinct class (State funds); special procedure reasonable, not discriminatory under Art.14.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.14; Chiranjit Lal Chowdhry v. Union of India

respondent_arguments.text: No violation of Art.19(1)(f)(g); procedure follows natural justice; self-imposed by contract.
Countersignature not required for Managing Director per Forms.

court_reasoning.text: Supplementary Covenant invalid; Rulers completely divested sovereignty under Art.VI on Aug 20, 1948; no competence for later amendment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.VI vests all rights, authority, jurisdiction in Union; no residue in Rulers.

court_reasoning.text: Even if Ordinances lapsed, Act continues proprio vigore in Patiala territory; appellants from Patiala area.
Dispute arises under Covenant (Art.X); barred by Art.363.
Patiala State Bank separate class (State funds for public benefit); special recovery reasonable, not violative of Art.14.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification valid per Chiranjit Lal, Ram Krishna Dalmia.
Per Madhya Pradesh v. G.C. Mandawar, Bhaiyalal Shukla.

court_reasoning.text: No violation Art.19(1)(g); recovery law not trade restriction. Procedure under Act/rules reasonable, complies natural justice (notice, hearing, appeal, revision); Managing Director unbiased.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules flexible; appellants did not contest liability, only sought time.

court_reasoning.text: Certificate valid; no countersignature needed for Managing Director per Forms.

holdings.text: Supplementary Covenant ineffective; but Act in force proprio vigore in Patiala territory; proceedings not barred by Art.363 for appellants.
Act and rules not violative of Art.14 or 19(1)(f)(g); Patiala State Bank distinct class; procedure reasonable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Promod Chandra Deb v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Loss of sovereignty may be continuing process.

precedents_cited.case_name: Virendra Singh v. State of Uttar Pradesh
Prithi Singh v. State of Pepsu
Bholanath J. Thaker v. State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.363 not bar if right independent of Covenant.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chiranjit Lal Chowdhry v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Single entity may be class under Art.14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S.R. Tendolkar

precedents_cited.relevance: State Bank dues separate class for recovery.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. G.C. Mandawar
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.14 applies to laws by same authority.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Gwalior Sugar Co. Ltd.
Bhaiyalal Shukla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Different laws in areas post-reorg valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Malik Ram v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Discretion to allow evidence in quasi-judicial proceedings.

statutes_cited.name: Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act, 2002 BK
statutes_cited.relevance: Recovery of dues to Patiala State Bank as arrears of land revenue; procedure upheld as valid.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Act not repugnant; provides reasonable procedure.

statutes_cited.name: States Reorganisation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Merger of Pepsu into Punjab; historical differences valid.

statutes_cited.name: Covenant for Pepsu (May 5, 1948)
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of powers; Ordinances extended laws but lapsed.

outcome.summary: All contentions rejected; appeals and writ petitions dismissed holding Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act and proceedings valid; not violative of Arts.14,19(1)(f)(g). Dissent by Subba Rao J. on Art.14.

key_quotes.text: "A State says Oppenheim, ceases to be an International Person when it ceases to exist."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains merger and loss of sovereignty under Covenant.

key_quotes.text: "The entirety of the rights, authority and jurisdiction of the Rulers is to vest in the Union."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The Patiala State Bank is a class by itself and it will be within the power of the State to enact a law with respect to it."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The creditor is made the judge of his cause and is empowered to determine the dues and realise them from the debtor."
key_quotes.speaker: Subba Rao, J.
key_quotes.significance: Dissent highlighting procedural unfairness under Art.14.
